awd_titl_txt: Enabling the Next Generation of Hazards Researchers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will (1) foster the development of scholars with a career-long commitment to research on hazards, risk, and disasters; (2) contribute to the nation's future research capacity and infrastructure in these areas; and (3) add important original scientific knowledge to the areas of hazards, risk, and disasters by increasing interdisciplinary, convergent scholarship. This project builds on previous successful mentoring projects funded by CMMI with some important innovations. First, this project will expand the substantive interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary content by including coverage of coupled hazards-society modeling, disaster health, and emerging technologies. Second, the project uses research on successful mentoring to design an early career faculty mentoring program that maximizes beneficial impacts for mentees, develops the skills of new mentors, and is transferable to a broad range of research mentoring contexts (e.g., university-based programs, other NSF programs). Third, there will be a greater emphasis on preparing mentees to pursue funding via the NSF's CAREER mechanism. Fourth, this project will establish a formal partnership between the Enabling Program and the Natural Hazards Center at the University of Colorado Boulder to improve program visibility and institutional capacity.
 
The program consists of several key elements: (a) a cohort of 20 Fellows who are in tenure track positions at research universities, (b) 10 senior scholars that will serve as Mentors to the Fellows, (c) a program Advisory Committee, and (c) a project Leadership Management Team consisting of the Principal and Co-Principal Investigators and several supporting members. This project is crucial to the advancement of knowledge in the interdisciplinary hazards/disasters/risk field, which relies on a continuous influx of young scholars committed both to their own disciplines and to the theoretical and applied aspects of this broad field. The significance of the program lies in developing and empowering a cadre of researchers who can understand and address the complex interactions between the social, built, and natural environment associated with hazards and disasters. In terms of broader impacts, the project will create a diverse set of scholars versed in the systematic explanation of social causes and consequences of disasters, which is critical to improving all phases of disaster management. Results will be disseminated, including a description and assessment of the transferable mentoring model, through journal article publications and participation in the annual Natural Hazards Research and Applications Workshop in Colorado.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the “Enabling Program” were to: (1) foster the development of scholars with a career-long commitment to research on hazards, risk, and disasters; (2) contribute to the nation's future research risk reduction capacity; and (3) add important original scientific knowledge by increasing interdisciplinary, convergent scholarship. The program was motivated by the need to advance knowledge and capacity in the field of hazards, risk, and disasters, which relies on a continuous influx of new scholars committed both to their own disciplines and to the theoretical and applied aspects of the much broader field. The significance of the program lies in developing and empowering a cadre of researchers who can understand and address complex interactions between the human,  built, and natural environments associated with hazards and disasters.

This was the fifth round of the Enabling Program funded by CMMI. In this iteration, we sought to build upon the successes of previous efforts while expanding the substantive multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary content. For the first time, the Mentors and Fellows had expertise in coupled hazards-society modeling, disaster health, and novel emerging technologies. The program also placed greater emphasis on preparing Fellows to pursue funding via the NSF's Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER). The CAREER Program is a foundation-wide activity that offers prestigious awards in support of early-career faculty who have the potential to serve as academic role models in research and education and to lead advances in the mission of their department or organization. CAREER recipients build a firm foundation for a lifetime of leadership in integrating education and research, and in the hazards and disaster field, in particular, awardees have made substantial contributions over the decades. During this fifth round, we also established a formal partnership between the Enabling Program and the Natural Hazards Center at the University of Colorado Boulder. This improved program visibility, sustainability and institutional capacity while also providing the first ever archive for all prior rounds of the program.

The program consisted of several key elements: (a) a cohort of 22 Fellows in tenure track positions at research universities (i.e. Assistant Professors), (b) 11 senior scholars that served as Mentors to the Fellows, (c) a program Advisory Committee, and (c) a project Leadership Management Team consisting of the Principal and Co-Principal Investigators and several supporting members. The project cultivated a diverse assembly of proficient, early-career scholars dedicated to the socio-technical facets of hazards, disasters, and risk to support groundbreaking research in these intertwined areas.

The program participants met twice during the first two years of the project. The initial launch meeting was held virtually in July 2020 (due to the COVID-19 pandemic) with the goal of introducing the Fellows, Mentors, Advisors, and Leadership team. The Principal Investigators reviewed the goals of the program and hosted a presentation on the NSF-HDBE program from former program director, Walter Peacock. We supplied structured counsel to Fellows through a mentoring system and auxiliary learning opportunities to empower them in formulating research proposals that were funded from various federal, state, and private entities. We also provided strategic advice to the Fellows on how to contribute significantly to the broader hazards, risk, and disasters field, while maintaining a distinct identity within their respective disciplines (e.g. Civil Engineering, Sociology, Geography, Urban Planning, Psychology). The second meeting was held in a hybrid format in July 2021 at the Institute of Behavioral Science at the University of Colorado Boulder. At this meeting, Fellows received feedback on their proposal drafts along with other mentoring regarding topics related to an academic career. This meeting was set to immediately precede the 46th Annual Natural Hazards Workshop and Researchers Meeting in Colorado, which several of the Fellows stayed on to attend and present their work. This was intended to foster integrating them into the hazards/disaster community.

Throughout the term of the project, which included two additional years, Fellows interacted with their Mentors to garner help in achieving their career goals which was done virtually and in-person at professional conferences. In partnership with the Natural Hazards Center and the NHERI CONVERGE facility at CU Boulder, we also invited Fellows to participate in many virtual workshops and early career training opportunities on current topics related to hazards and disasters research. 

An assessment in July 2023 revealed that the Fellows were impressively awarded 25 NSF grants totaling $9,492,486 as PI or co-PI (an average of $379,699 per grant). Most notably, three CAREER grants were awarded along with 80 non-NSF grants from other agencies. In addition, the Fellows published more than 200 peer-reviewed articles during the project term. Of note, the Fellows and Mentors comprised the most diverse group of hazards, risk and disaster scholars in the Enabling Program’s history.
